title: 103_s1439
content: After a formal complaint is filed, the employee and the head of the office can resolve the issues, withdraw the complaint, or enter into a written agreement with the Director's approval. Intimidation is prohibited. SEC. 12 prohibits intimidation of House of Representatives employees by Members, officers, or employees, and SEC. 13 addresses confidentiality. SEC. 13 ensures confidentiality in counseling, mediation, and hearings, with exceptions for judicial review. Employees' party affiliation, domicile, and political compatibility with the employing office are not violations in employment decisions. The term "employee" includes congressional staff members, committee staff, and officers elected by the House of Representatives or Senate. An employee in Congress can be elected or appointed by a Member of the House of Representatives or a Senator, excluding certain types of employees. This also includes applicants for positions filled by these individuals. No Congressional employee can sue to address prohibited practices under section 4, except as allowed by this Act. Technical amendments are made to the Civil Rights Act of 1991 regarding government employee rights. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 aims to protect certain government employees from discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, or disability. Violations of this act are defined as practices that go against the provisions outlined in section 302, which prohibits discriminatory practices. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, or disability in personnel actions. It repeals certain sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1991. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 prohibits discrimination in personnel actions based on various factors. It repeals sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, Fair Labor Standards Amendments of 1989, and Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. Additionally, certain rules of the House of Representatives are also repealed. SEC. 17. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "congressional employee" includes employees of the House of Representatives, Senate, and certain instrumentalities. An "employee of an instrumentality" refers to employees of specific entities listed in the Act. The term "employee of the House of Representatives" refers to individuals eligible to file complaints with the Office of Fair Employment Practice. The term "employee of the Senate" includes certain individuals as defined in the Act. The term "employee of the Senate" includes individuals whose pay is disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate, employees of the Architect of the Capitol assigned to specific areas, applicants for certain positions, and former employees with claims arising from Senate employment. The term "employing office" refers to the office headed by a head of an employing office. The term "head of an employing office" refers to the individual with final authority over Senate employee appointments, hiring, discharge, and terms. "Violation" is defined as a breach of regulations under section 4(c). The term "head of an employing office" has final authority over Senate employee appointments, hiring, discharge, and terms. "Violation" is a breach of regulations under section 4(c).
